Mortuaries, funeral homes, etc are privately-owned businesses. So legally, they can refuse a service whenever they want.

Then have him sitting on my shelf staring at me for the rest of my life. "You did this to me" I can hear it saying in my mind when I'm at my lowest in grief.
If you can handle it emotionally and mentally go for it, but I feel like it would be harder than you think to do it. There is like this shield between you and a random animal where it doesn't bother you as much, but when it's your beloved pet? Wow I envy you. I'd love to be able to do it but I just don't think I could.


Now, as for your body, I'd LOVE to be able to donate my body to science. Specifically The Body Farm in Knoxville, Tennessee.

John Paul Jones, an American Naval Captain and one of the most pivotal members of the early stages of the Navy, was buried in France. He, like other historic Americans from the 1700s, was loved and adored by the French. America started searching for John's body to put it in the Naval Academy some century and a half later or so. After finding it, the body had barely decomposed. The French had mummified him, a little. They used a cloth to wrap just a layer of two, applied alcohol, and repeated. This method kept Jones' figure almost identical to his in the late 1700s when he had passed.

I know the existence of an almost perfect method of corpse conservation and it is called "parafinado" (spanish for paraffin). It was developed by the very famous Spanish-Argentian doctor and scientist Pedro Ara who applied this technique to, for example, Eva Perón whose body remains intact from the day of her death back in 1952. A great example of this technique is the head of an old man exposed in the Anatomy Museum of the Hospital de Clinicas in Cordoba city, Argentina (http://www.museoara.fcm.unc.edu.ar/?page_id=60 here are photos of the head and how it looks today)
Unfortunately, Pedro Ara never told anyone the secrets and ways of his technique and he died being the only person capable of performing it.

História

￼Capa do filme O Nascimento de uma Nação (1915)

A primeira Ku Klux Klan na verdade foi fundada pelo general Nathan Bedford Forrest da cidade de Pulaski, Tennessee, em 1865 após o final da Guerra Civil Americana. Seu objetivo era impedir a integração social dos negros recém-libertados, como por exemplo, adquirir terras e ter direitos concedidos aos outros cidadãos, como votar. O nome, cujo registro mais antigo é de 1867, parece derivar da palavra grega kýklos(do grego κύκλος), que significa "círculo", "anel", e da palavra inglesa clan (clã) escrita com k. Devido aos métodos violentos da KKK, há a hipótese de o nome ter-se inspirado no som feito quando se coloca um rifle pronto para atirar. provavelmente o nome também pode ter origem no nome de um templo maia, chamado kukulcán. onde segundo os maias, "kukul" significa sagrado ou divino e "can" significa serpente, mas não existem dados que comprovem isso.[

yo,,, people are so unimaginative. like, i get cultural ideologies but what if my mom agrees to me keeping her skull after shes dead?? its her choice. you can very easily preserve a skull. just remove the tissue, do a bit of boiling, maybe coat it with something to protect it from dust. its no different than violently burning the shit out of your mom until shes a pile of ashes. and then grinding her bones to dust if they dont turn to ash in the oven. like, dont say taxidermy or any other sort of after death method is weird or creepy when its completely acceptable to slap some makeup on a dead bodys face, some clothes, and then set it in a box for EVERYONE at the funeral to see before they bury it. those dead bodys probably also have wires sewn through the jaw to keep it shut, maybe glue to keep the eyes closed. like??? its so dumb to me that people see THAT as acceptable and everything else is wildly creepy or wrong. i get it, its mostly cultural but it just seems shallow and boring. im thinking of keeping my bull terriers skull when he dies, or maybe even freeze drying him. it is no different than keeping a jar of his ashes. at least if hes a skull or freeze dried, i can still pet his big ole nose. hes a beautiful dog, who wouldnt want to be able to see him and remember what a joy he was in life?? if souls exist, its already off on his merry way when hes dead. its not bad to want keep the rest of him close, to remind you of the happiness he brought.

In fact it's not really true that it can not be done. When for a short time I was studying to be a nurse we went to a anotomic museum from a medical university nearby and they did have bodies from real people in all shapes and form to show how the bodies looked on the inside. Mainly they did peel of layers of skin and flesh on one side to show the "insite" but for like half of the body part they did leave the skin on. They only took care that you can not recognize the persons face out of respect for the family. It was kind of weird looking at it. The way it was made it was somehow difficult to realize it where real people, but when I saw the body of a woman who died of cancer during labor ( the baby was still in her belly almost coming out) it was also very confronting. Also they have a museum in Amsterdam called body works where they used real bodies to show to the people. But I don't think you can ask for this as a private person for in your livingroom ( thank God, I also don't like animal to be stuffed). These are from people who gave their body up for medical research and meanly for educational purpose.

There are two kinds of embalming - arterial and cavity. Arterial embalming is the kind usually done, it does a fine job of preserving the deceased long enough for relatives to arrive in the area and services to be conducted. In arterial embalming, the blood is pumped out of the body and embalming fluid is pumped in. Lincoln had to have been cavity embalmed. In cavity embalming, the internal organs are either removed and the body cavity is stuffed to produce a natural appearance, or an incision is made and the internal organs are "pickled" with embalming fluid, then the body is embalmed via the arteries.

Also, the term we used in the funeral home to describe cremated remains was "cremains".

If anyone's more interested in Jeremy Bentham's head and how it was stolen:
It is his actual skeleton in the case, on display in his own clothes. After the mummification of his head didn't go to plan, a wax head was commissioned, but the real one was on display by his feet.
In 1989 boys from a rival university (King's College) snuck in, stole his real mummified head, and apparently played football with it. When it was retrieved it was even more damaged than before, so far safe keeping they locked the head away and took it off display.
King's College then stole the wax head the year after.
At the moment, from when I last went, the head was kept in a black box and pressing a button with UV light would reveal it!

To answer why we don't taxidermy humans: although taxidermists do their best to preserve the skin of the animal when skinning the animal (as in, doing their best not to cut the animal's skin into a million pieces,) there will still be cuts. When the animal is fitted over it's mannequin or mold, these cuts are sewn together and obviously covered by fur. Humans... Dont... have fur.
We actually have taxidermied humans before... Once. It happened in the 1830s (Victorians, I know, are you really that surprised?) to an African man. He's named "Negro of Banyoles" - you can look it up. It's not horrifying, it just looked like a sculpture of a human that was kind of.... off. In 2000, most of his remains were sent back to Africa for final burial.

TLDR: Humans dont have fur to cover the seams of taxidermy.

What's left over after the cremation process, I can assure you all, is NOT ash. Please, Stop calling cremated remains "ashes" they are NOT ashes. What is left over is frontal bone of the cranium, sternum,  the ends of the long bones, sacrum, coccyx, and parts of the pelvis. These are then pulverized and sifted with a magnet to remove pins, arterial stents, and fasteners from the container the body was cremated in, and run through a blender of sorts creating a powder mistakenly called ashes. If what you receive in the urn from the crematory looks gray or white like ash then somebody F'd up the process.

If anyone wants to be taxidermed, (or as near as you can get), then donate your body to Gunther Von Hagens. He is a artist who uses dead bodies in his work, some say gruesome, others say great. Why not just point people to Tideland. That's a pretty good case against taxidermy (and chilling). Also, Bodyworlds should have a small disclaimer in your video, I think, since its plastination of bodies has been called into question - as far as what bodies were actually legally donated, and which ones were possibly gotten through other means. The other thing about "getting permission" from a mortuary - the morgue has no legal claim so the woman in the vid should simply have taken the body, dry-iced it and called around to find someone who would be willing to do it. A mortuary isn't going to do it, since that's not what they do. The case as presented shortly in the video makes no sense, was the wife actually expecting a morgue to skin him and do all of that? All they know how to do is embalm a body. Most don't even do cremations on site.

Why don't we cryopreserve humans, now that is the question. The basic technology has been around since the late 1960s, and has, despite minimal funding, become quite advanced in the last decade or so. It's quite insane, really; ignoring cryonics is like ignoring the lifeboats on a sinking ship. When you ask people why they don't  sign up for (or at least support) cryonics, they come up with the strangest and most infantile excuses. Yes, excuses, that's all they are. There is no rational argument against trying to preserve the dead to the best of our abilities. Overpopulation, boredom, can't turn a hamburger into a cow... I've heard them all before and they make no sense at all. Not then, not now, not ever. It's funny / sad to see otherwise seemingly intelligent people fail so badly at logic and reason when it comes to aging, death, and cryopreservation. More people (almost twice as many, in fact) have been to space than have been frozen. It's a psychosis, and it has a name: deathism. It's basically a mix of Sour Grapes and Stockholm Syndrome, a once-useful defense mechanism that has not just become obsolete, but lethal. But whatever. Pearls before swine, eh?

The part that gets me, is how morality is influencing individual rights. How can your human body not be your own property, if it's not your property than this also means you have no right to decide whatever happens to your body after your death (including: where it get's buried). in other words your body could be used for scientific research without your consent, or your organs could be harvested and sold without your consent. Now I know what most of you are thinking... it ain't nothing like that, there are laws in place, etc... but these laws are build on very weak principles (note: that somehow these laws only apply to putting your body on display & unconventional treatments). The way I see it, everybody has the rights on their own body... and therefor should be able to do with it what he or she wants. And if you think about it technically this also means a body can never be stolen from a cemetery, since the cemetery nor your beloved ones have ownership over you... these laws sound pretty sketchy...

For the sake of discussion. Perhaps a more practical of being immortalized would be to use scanning technology to scan and store a detailed three dimensional copy of your living body. It's like a digitized photo, but with all the information need to create an exact replica of your body right down to the smallest detail. 3-D printers are now becoming more commonplace and more sophisticated. So, we should eventually have one sophisticated enough to produce a more lifelike "statue" of your living self than can be achieved with taxidermy. This would also allow one to save a replica of one's younger self just as one might save a photo on a DVD. Imagine when you are older being able to meet your younger self. Also, there is no law against owning an exact replica of one's body.

The current laws regarding the disposal of a corpse are grounded in the past understanding of sanitary disposal. It was to prevent the spread of diseases. The legislation needs to be updated to acknowledge that there are now safe ways to preserve a corpse so that it can be sanitary. So, people need to ask the government to change the law to allow people to own a corpse when properly prepared.

@Vsauce Can you do a video about clones? I'm curious about the subject. If you had a clone made exactly the same as you, with the same memories and etcetera... Are they really you? 
So what would make you different from your clone? You can't control two people at once, but your concious is the exact same as theirs. Therefore, what's that difference? 

So, for example. I walked into the same room as my clone. That clone proceeded to kill me... Would I then become the clone? Theoretically, that's impossible but then you think that they're the exact same as you in every way.
So something has to separate you from your clone, so is it really your clone? 

Anyone else get what I'm trying to say? I find the whole subject mind blowing. I could donate my blood in the hope that I'd be cloned in the future but what good would that do me? I would die. I'd cease to exist but my clone, who is the exact same in every way would be me, but not me?

Isn't shooting human remains or anything else permanently far away into outerspace a waste of resources needed so much back on earth? 300 cremated dead people in space does nothing. And some people are worth getting rid forever, like for example the leader of North Korea and the dude that stole my bike. But if in some weird future or some strange fashion statement, billions of people send their remains into outer space every year. Won`t we lose all that valuable water, minerals and other potential raw material that is within their dead bodies? Assuming we don't change our locust like behavior. Our population keeps on growing out of proportion and we use up more resources faster than our planet can regenerate. With dwindling resources and facing aspects of mass starvation and the ensuing wars on the remaining resouces, could it happen that things like human ethics or moral code may be replaced with very cold and efficient pragmatism? Like recycling or reusing our dead bodies into something useful instead of leaving it to rot or shoot it into outer space. Like compulsory organ donation / redistribution or blood donation after that person dies. Or recycling human dead meat into jerky meat, diamonds, clothes or into a new iphone. Yea I know its disgusting and moraly wrong and unethical. And vegans may agree with me that life is sacred and stuff. But hey. Junkies sniff up the cremated remains of their dead relatives when they are short on drugs. Desperation and the sheer will of surviving does turn some people into monsters. And talking of short of supplies. If that kind of scenario becomes reality, maybe out of necessity cannibalism becomes legalized and shooting dead bodies into outer space is outlawed.

Lawyers don't usually conceive of physical (or intangible) things as "property".  My TV is not "property"--rather, I have property rights IN the TV.  

It's not a big deal in casual conversation, but, for law types, the abstraction's important, because property rights are subdivisible, and it's possible for many people to have property rights in the same item (for example, my right to possess my house is a property right, but so is the bank's right to seize and sell it if I don't pay them back).

The '-ed & -ied' at the end of each word make them past tense, but, 'taxidermied' is the correct tense for 'taxedermy' in the past tense. 'Taxidermize and taxidermize' are not real words, at one point there were, but are no longer, so you can't use them without being wrong. That is the rule for most verb tenses, I believe at least. So: 
'I am going to taxidermy my cat' is future-tense
'I got my cat taxidermied' is past-tense
I don't think there is a present-tense that is correct. :/

Also skin varies in thickness which adds another problem. Professional taxidermists definitely have a lot of skill.

But, I would disagree, unless you have an underlying medical condition that makes your organs unusable (like a tumour no one knew was growing in you), your body wasn't immediately put on life sustaining machines, or the organ was damaged (say, dropped), most likely anything you donate will be used - donor organs are in such short supply that they use literally every possible organ they can, to help save a life (or many lives).

You do have to die in a hospital, or be transferred to one very quickly, to donate your organs, but they do not remove the organs within an hour - in fact, maybe donor bodies are kept upwards of 6 months after their "death". The reason you need to be at a hospital is so they can put you on life support, that keeps your blood pumping to the organs. Generally they will want to put your organs in a transplant patient quickly, but it can wait, it's once they are removed that there is a deadline.

A 2-year-old died in Italy, 1920. Rosalia Lombardo resides in a glass coffin in Capuchin Catacombs in Palermo, Italy.
Ms Lombardo was preserved with a combination of formalin, zinc salts, alcohol, salicylic acid, and glycerin. Formalin, to kill bacteria, salicylic acid to kill fungi, alcohol to dry the body out and mummify it, and glycerin to keep her from getting too dry. Embalmers don’t use zinc anymore, but that’s supposedly the key ingredient for Lombardo’s successful embalming

Earth has two sets of poles. There are the magnetic poles that can be found using a compass.

Then there are the geographical poles. These are the points around which the earth spins. If you took a giant rod, skewered the planet, and spun it, the point where the rod penetrates the earth would be the north and south poles.

There is no east/west axis. They are the directions which indicate whether you are traveling with or against the direction of the earth's rotation.
if they sent a dead body into space it wouldn't deteriorate would it?

Even if we didn't have a magnetic field, there wouldn't be a west or east pole. The north and south pole are just naturally there, we can measure where they are using a compass. East and west are just concepts created by people to make it easier to navigate and whatnot.

However, in a way, I guess you could say that the international date line is kind of the east and west pole, if you really wanted to. But that's just because people decided it should be like that.

Because space is pretty empty.  The signals don't have much to collide with.  There is almost no interference while it is traveling through space.  

It also depends on how much power the signal is being transmitted with.  Usually high frequency (in audio, anyways) needs less power than low frequency.  That's why when you have woofers, they usually need an amplifier.  

Wireless is typically in the higher frequency ranges (between 2.4, 3.6 and 5GHz.) While SSTV is between 300Hz and 3400Hz

I don't know about blind people, but I've read about deaf:
They think in the same language they were taught, but they don't exactly "hear" themselves speaking (aka inner monologue), but rather imagine corresponding body movements instead.
This was studied on deaf from birth people who later in their lives had their hearing restored.
Those humans also have their hearing centre in the brain barely developed so they substitute it with visual and tactile information while thinking.

Fun fact: cremation isn't the only disposal alternative to burial; mulching is one option. There are a few different methods but the one I find most interesting is one developed by a Swedish company that involves freeze-drying the remains then breaking the body down using ultrasound. The end product is a rich fertilizer that can be used by the deceased's family to create a living memorial. It's quite poetic IMHO.

one answer is that everything would be pitch black.
"color" is white light refracted (split). the color that bounces back from an object is what color we define the object to be. Black objects don't reflect light at all, so we say they have an absence of color.

another answer is it would be in grey scale.
If you were to eliminate the ability of light to split, everything would be white, black, or some shade of grey (black areas within a white object) More black areas = darker grey.
